author: Sephtex
body:
Involved modules/technologies:
* Az
* docker

**Scope**

When using powershell inside docker, and using azure, then you might want to preserve the azure authentication. So next time the docker container you will use, will still have the azure credentials, and we don't need to provide them again. This is helpful when spawning multiple docker instances with multiple commands, one after the other.

**docker command example**
```
docker run -ti --rm \
	  -e USER=$USER \
	  -e HOSTNAME=$HOSTNAME \
	  -e SSH_AUTH_SOCK=/ssh-agent \
	  -v $(SOURCE_PATH)/build/.Azure:/home/user/.Azure \
	  -v $(SOURCE_PATH)/build/.Azure-IdentityService:/home/user/.local/share/.IdentityService \
	  -v ~/.ssh/id_rsa:/home/user/.ssh/id_rsa \
	  -v ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub:/home/user/.ssh/id_rsa.pub \
	  powershell-image-name:TAG <cmd>
```

We mounted the ~/.Azure directory in the past, but somehow/somewhere the .IdentityService directory seemed to be added as a needed directory to keep the credentials working.

I noticed by executing:
```
PS> Get-AzContextAutosaveSetting
Mode             : CurrentUser
ContextDirectory : /home/user/.Azure
ContextFile      : AzureRmContext.json
CacheDirectory   : /home/user/.IdentityService
CacheFile        : msal.cache
Settings         : {}
```

That `/home/user/.IdentityService` didn't existed, but when searching though all changed files, I found it at the location:
```
/home/user/.local/share/.IdentityService
```

Which seems it isn't respecting the AzContextAutosaveSetting.
